1. New - Servlet
2. Type in Package and Class-name
3. Click Finish

We need more information on this to reproduce/fix.  First, you opened this against WTP 3.0, but state below 3.3.0 as the Build ID- if you mean Eclipse 3.3.0, you probably mean WTP 2.0.

I tried it with the latest 2.0.2 and 3.0 M4 builds, but neither reproduced this problem.  However, you don't state if you created a Dynamic Web project first (and if you did, what was the Servlet version and was it targetted at a server?)

The line in question (which hasn't changed since 2.0 was released) is:
IFile file = (IFile) javaProject.findType(className).getResource();

Now, there is a very good chance that, if something went horribly wrong, javaProject is null.  But, we would need either a zip file of your workspace or else directions on exactly what the project name and type were (and what servers were defined, etc.) in order to reproduce this problem.  Please attach this information and reopen this bug.

Eclipse Version: 3.3.0 Build id: M20070921-1145 (Europa)
Web Standard Tools (WST) Project 2.0.1.v200709110510

Steps To Reproduce:
1. New-Other-Dynamic Web Project, Project name: webtest
2. Target Runtime: Apache Tomcat v5.5
3. Finish
4. File-New-Other-Servlet
5. Any Packagename (e.g. com.msf) and Classname (e.g. TestService)
6. Finish
7. Instead the java-file with the classname the exception in the .log file in my workspace was produced
8. The packagestructure (com/msf) was created
